results.title: To Improve Public Housing, New York City Moves to Tear It Down
results.abstract: After surveying residents at two developments in Manhattan, the agency is moving forward with a $1.5 billion plan to demolish and replace the buildings.

results.abstract: The police added 80 officers to the subway system after a man was fatally stabbed and three women were slashed in the legs in separate attacks over the weekend.

results.title: Improper Covid Aid Flowed to Fishery Businesses, Official Finds
results.abstract: Nearly half of $14.4 million dispensed to seafood processors, charter boats and other businesses in New Jersey during the pandemic may have to be paid back.
des_facet: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

multimedia.caption: Fishery businesses in New Jersey received $14.4 million in Covid relief aid. But the state comptroller says nearly half of that was improperly awarded.

results.title: Ocasio-Cortez’s Unusual Place in N.Y. City Council Races: The Sidelines
results.abstract: With early voting in the New York City Council primaries underway, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has yet to endorse any candidate.

results.abstract: As fewer suburbanites commute to the city, their fear and loathing has grown, as have tensions between city and suburban officials.

results.title: Ex-Lawyer Who Killed Girlfriend Dies in Custody Days Before Sentencing

results.title: Magda Saleh, Influential Egyptian Ballerina, Is Dead at 79
results.abstract: Trained at the Bolshoi, she became a star of the Cairo Ballet and played a key role in making ballet accessible to people of all classes.

multimedia.caption: Magda Saleh in an undated photograph. The Egyptian press called her Cairo’s first prima ballerina, but she often said that she was less interested in galas and glamour than in exposing people to ballet.
multimedia.copyright: via Magda Saleh

multimedia.caption: Magda Saleh in an undated photograph. The Egyptian press called her Cairo’s first prima ballerina, but she often said that she was less interested in galas and glamour than in exposing people to ballet.

results.title: A Walk Through the Past in New York
results.abstract: Ahead of next year’s 400th anniversary of the Dutch colony of New Netherland, the historian and author of “The Island at the Center of the World” offers a walking tour of often-overlooked Native American and Black sites.

multimedia.caption: In the 1600s, the Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam was situated on what is now the southern tip of Manhattan, the present location of the Financial District.

results.title: Can’t Repeat the Past? An Immersive ‘Great Gatsby’ Thinks You Can.
results.abstract: The theatrical performance of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s 1925 novel, opening this month at the Park Central Hotel, is the latest in a very long, heavily sequined line of “Gatsby” adaptations.

multimedia.caption: Claire Saunders, left, and Jillian Anne Abaya perform in an immersive-theater version of “The Great Gatsby.” The book’s copyright expired in 2021, and it has been widely adapted since then.

results.title: Jack McNally, N.Y.P.D. Detective Turned Defense Sleuth, Dies at 89
results.abstract: After he helped collar the men behind New York City’s biggest jewel heist, he worked as a private investigator for defendants like O.J. Simpson and Patty Hearst.

multimedia.caption: The police detective turned private investigator Jack McNally, left, with the lawyer F. Lee Bailey, right, and another lawyer, Henry Gonzales, on a break during the robbery trial of Patty Hearst in San Francisco in 1976.

results.title: The New War on Bad Air
results.abstract: A century ago, a well-ventilated building was considered good medicine. But by the time Covid-19 arrived, our buildings could barely breathe. How did that happen? And how do we let the fresh air back in?

results.title: Accused in Missing Man’s Grisly Killing: His Ex-Wife and Her Husband
results.abstract: Three years ago, Steven Kraft disappeared. This week, Jamie and Nicholas Orsini were arrested and accused of carrying out an elaborate plot to kill him and dispose of his body.

results.title: Richard Severo, Times Reporter in Internal Clash Over Book, Dies at 90

results.abstract: Michael Olson, 54, flew the girl around the country, passing her off as his daughter, prosecutors said. He kept spreadsheets of children he contacted, they said.

results.title: De Blasio Owes City $475,000 for Bringing Police on Presidential Campaign
results.abstract: New York City’s Conflicts of Interest Board said the former mayor must reimburse the city for police officers’ travel, and pay a record fine.

multimedia.caption: The former mayor’s campaign lasted just four months in 2019. According to the Conflicts of Interest Board, the city spent $319,794.20 in travel-related costs for members of his security detail.
multimedia.copyright: Travis Dove for The New York Times
